pullRequest.body:
Define the (Shannon) binary and q-ary entropy functions.

The binary entropy function is used in information theory; for example, in Shannon's theorems.

---

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [x] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->
- [x] depends on: #14594
- [x] depends on: #15828
- [x] depends on: #15829

The lemmas are mostly "trivial", especially using `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.NegMulLog`.
This is the kind of application that `NegMulLog` was made for.

If Mathlib is to include Shannon's theorems in the future (already formalized in Coq), this might hopefully save someone a few minutes.

nodes.body: Shouldn't binary entropy be put under InformationTheory? Why not use capital H_2 for the function's name?

@kspalaiologos Thanks for the comment! I moved it to `InformationTheory`. For the name, did you mean to use  `Hâ‚‚` or `H_2`? The danger is that it might be confused with RÃ©nyi entropy (collision entropy), which is written `Hâ‚‚`.

@b-mehta and I have material about the binary entropy function. We needed it a year ago in the context of the progress on the Frankl set family conjecture. I suggest we wait for Bhavik to provide the code to compare.
Yes, I developed that further since this function is fundamental to my Ramsey proof. I will make a detailed comparison in the next day or two.
@b-mehta Any news? If you're too busy, you could also upload your files and let someone else compare it...

@YaelDillies @lecopivo @semorrison  
It seems that @b-mehta is not available at the moment. Would you propose to wait or maybe continue with this?
Hopefully I can find the relevant files in the `ramsey` branch of mathlib3.

I guess it's this file?
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/blob/exponential-ramsey/src/information_theory/binary_entropy.lean
It allows arbitrary base for the logs while I use 2. Maybe I should generalize everything and put 2 as the default base...
I need a few things myself about the binary entropy. Mind if I touch this PR?

> I need a few things myself about the binary entropy. Mind if I touch this PR?

Sure, go for it!
@YaelDillies Can you think of anything I could do to increase the chances of this getting merged?

Sorry, I am not done adding the material because I ran out of Lean time for my holidays. I won't have more time until July.

However there are things you can do in the meantime, eg give up binary entropy (for now) and only define base e entropy. This is much easier because `log` has more API than `logb` and also nicer expressions.

You can then relegate binary entropy to a second PR depending on the present one.

@YaelDillies By "entropy", do you mean for arbitrary probability distributions? That seems like a major API decision for Mathlib, which concerns the entire way how "probability" is set up (which I don't even understand at the moment). Not sure if I can really do anything useful there. Or did you mean something else?
Sorry, I got my terminology wrong. Replace "binary entropy" with "base 2 binary entropy" and "entropy" with "binary entropy" in my previous message and everything should hopefully make sense.

@YaelDillies Since I seem to be prone to misunderstanding you, just to clarify: You're saying I should replace all `log2` by `log` in the current file? 

I don't really see how that's *much* easier but could certainly do it. However, people who might be using this API one day might want the binary-log version as well. Could also make a general version that allows setting the base and having a default.

Yes that's what I mean.

> I don't really see how that's _much_ easier but could certainly do it.

It's much easier because the preliminary API lemmas about `log` already exists. This is not the case with `logb`, cf the ton of lemmas I had to add in my last few commits. The general case would be nice to have but I would argue it should be a separate definition (instead of replacing the base e one) in order to have one API without all the `log b` factors.

@YaelDillies another question: The way to "get up to date with master" is to merge it, as you did? I had previously rebased (which I now probably wouldn't do since you have also worked on the branch). The docs (https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html#dealing-with-merge-conflicts) aren't very explicit about this. Thanks for the help!

Guess I will merge master again before changing the logarithm base.
Yes, merging is the usual thing. You can of course rebase and I really don't mind if I lose authorship of some commits ðŸ˜„

@YaelDillies I reversed your additions to [Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/Log/Base.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9734/commits/ed98ab123b247f3dd17be7028c92849a0886cf43#diff-65f5aea892f7b42adf3f0b41b364a438db50e26b67e23a0ca2e20a095cf9ac8a) and [Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/Log/NegMulLog.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9734/commits/ed98ab123b247f3dd17be7028c92849a0886cf43#diff-5262eb8af9650701e05eee3fa60cb996837b1fbdc9c983f031d182b6072f7c0f) because they are not needed for this PR any longer (what with using natural logs) and they no longer worked with the current master branch.
That's fine. Please just keep them on a branch somewhere so that we can add them when needed.

> That's fine. Please just keep them on a branch somewhere so that we can add them when needed.

The branch: [Yael-logb-lemmas](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/Yael-logb-lemmas)
Note: these are only those changes that didn't work with master and that I removed in [ed98ab1](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9734/commits/ed98ab123b247f3dd17be7028c92849a0886cf43). All other changes are still in this PR.

I've opened #12693. Would you mind either
* Removing the corresponding lines from the diff and updating the labels, assuming this PR doesn't need the new lemmas.
* Marking this PR as depending on #12693.

@YaelDillies  This PR does not require #12693. I removed the changes as you suggested. This PR now just adds `BinEntropy.lean`, nothing else.

By "updating labels", do you mean the PR labels on GitHub? Feel free to change those, I'm not sure what they should be.

Hi, great to have some people working on entropies! Are you aware of https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10493 and should the binary entropy be based on it? I think at least the following lemmas follow trivially from the general case:

- `h2_gt_0` holds by `measureEntropy_nonneg` and `measureEntropy_dirac`
- `h2_zero_iff_zero_or_one` by `measureEntropy_dirac`
- `h2_one_iff_eq_half` by `measureEntropy_eq_card_iff_measure_eq`
- `h2_le_log_2` by `measureEntropy_le_log_card `
- `hâ‚‚_continuous` (not in #10493, I think; If I understand correctly, the lemma refers to continuity of the function $h2$ in $p$. It follows since the Bernoulli distribution is continuous in $p$ and the entropy is continuous in the distribution (even concave, see below).
- `strictConcave_h2` (not in #10493, I think)

> Shouldn't binary entropy be put under InformationTheory? Why not use capital H_2 for the function's name?
-- https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9734#issuecomment-1890888657

> @kspalaiologos Thanks for the comment! I moved it to InformationTheory. For the name, did you mean to use Hâ‚‚ or H_2? The danger is that it might be confused with RÃ©nyi entropy (collision entropy), which is written Hâ‚‚.
-- https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9734#issuecomment-1890962843


About the naming, you are currently using both `h2` and `hâ‚‚`. I think it should be only one of them. Other possible, less ambiguous names: `Hbin`, `Hbern`, where the latter is consistent with `Hm` (entropy of a measure #10493), but to my experience less conventional in Information Theory than `Hbin`.

$h_2$ could be a differential Renyi-2-entropy, but this is maybe not that frequent.
In general, $H_2, h, h_2$ could all have naming collisions.
To follow the capitalisation rules, it should be `hbin`/`hbern`.

Very nice to see some work on information theory! Just one initial comment: I really think it should be named something longer, i.e. `binaryEntropy` seems like the obvious name. `hâ‚‚` can then be used as local notation for it where appropriate, but reserving this name for all time seems a bit extreme (i.e. I use `hâ‚‚` all the time for hypothesis names...).

Also, it might be good to generalize it to the q-ary entropy (see, e.g., [this book](https://cse.buffalo.edu/faculty/atri/courses/coding-theory/book/), section 3.3).

> Also, it might be good to generalize it to the q-ary entropy (see, e.g., [this book](https://cse.buffalo.edu/faculty/atri/courses/coding-theory/book/), section 3.3).

This was roughly the state of the PR before I told Adomas to use `log` instead of `logb`. My motivation is that the `logb` API is very underdeveloped compared to the `log` API and that the `binaryEntropy` defined using `log` has a nicer derivative (which I need in an upcoming PR).

My opinion is that the `q`-ary entropy function should be a separate function, and be defined in a later PR.

I didn't mean to change the base of the log; I'm perfectly happy with the natural log. I only meant to add the `x * log (q-1)` term. Once we have that, I really don't see the point of having a separate case for `q=2`, it's literally just `qaryEntropy 2`.

Yes, so `qaryEntropy 2` is not "literally just" the definition in this PR because this PR uses base e, not base 2.

Or do you mean that q-ary entropy does not need to use log base 2?

- Given that this is going into `SpecialFunctions`, I currently tend toward **naming** it `binaryEntropy` as suggested by @dupuisf.
- Concerning #10493, I didn't know about this PR. Thanks for pointing it out. I think if this is going into `SpecialFunctions`, it would make sense to prove the properties here like this for now and then later prove that this definition equals the Shannon entropy of a Bernoulli distribution once #10493 is merged. I'm open to shortening the proofs here later using things from general entropy. However, if we treat `binaryEntropy` as a "special function that maps Real -> Real", a user of the API shouldn't need to define a random variable (or even know what that is) to use the function and its properties as far as they only concern the function itself (e.g. concavity, differentiability...).
- I'm interested in opinions what **namespace** this should be in.
-  The **q-ary entropy**, according to that book, seems to be a slightly different thing. I'm talking about the Shannon entropy of a Bernoulli random variable (as [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)) does). One can measure this in bits (base-2 logs), Nats (natural logs), etc. The definition of q-ary entropy isn't the same, as the book points out, (even though they coincide for base-2 logs). So I would say those definitions are separate. Alternatively, one could fix the base to two (I used base-two logs originally) and *force* them to coincide.

> * if we treat `binaryEntropy` as a "special function that maps Real -> Real", a user of the API shouldn't need to define a random variable (or even know what that is) to use the function and its properties as far as they only concern the function itself (e.g. concavity, differentiability...)

Agreed. That is precisely my use case.

> Yes, so `qaryEntropy 2` is not "literally just" the definition in this PR because this PR uses base e, not base 2.
> 
> Or do you mean that q-ary entropy does not need to use log base 2?

Right, I see no particular reason why q-ary entropy needs to be in base q, especially if all other versions of entropy are using natural logs.
Okay then I'm happy for this PR to be about the base e q-ary entropy!

> * Given that this is going into `SpecialFunctions`, I currently tend toward **naming** it `binaryEntropy` as suggested by @dupuisf.
> 
>     * Concerning [feat: entropy of a measure #10493](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10493), I didn't know about this PR. Thanks for pointing it out. I think if this is going into `SpecialFunctions`, it would make sense to prove the properties here like this for now and then later prove that this definition equals the Shannon entropy of a Bernoulli distribution once [feat: entropy of a measure #10493](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10493) is merged. I'm open to shortening the proofs here later using things from general entropy. However, if we treat `binaryEntropy` as a "special function that maps Real -> Real", a user of the API shouldn't need to define a random variable (or even know what that is) to use the function and its properties as far as they only concern the function itself (e.g. concavity, differentiability...).
> 
>     * I'm interested in opinions what **namespace** this should be in.
> 
>     * The **q-ary entropy**, according to that book, seems to be a slightly different thing. I'm talking about the Shannon entropy of a Bernoulli random variable (as [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)) does). One can measure this in bits (base-2 logs), Nats (natural logs), etc. The definition of q-ary entropy isn't the same, as the book points out, (even though they coincide for base-2 logs). So I would say those definitions are separate. Alternatively, one could fix the base to two (I used base-two logs originally) and _force_ them to coincide.

No, q-ary entropy is very much a generalization of the binary entropy: it's the Shannon entropy of a random variable over {1,...,q}, where 1 has probability 1-x and the rest of the probability is evenly distributed over the rest. It's used for things like bounding the volume of Hamming balls and that sort of thing, much like the binary entropy. And if we're going to standardize to natural logs for defining various versions of the entropy, it should also follow suit.

> * However, if we treat `binaryEntropy` as a "special function that maps Real -> Real", a user of the API shouldn't need to define a random variable (or even know what that is) to use the function and its properties as far as they only concern the function itself (e.g. concavity, differentiability...).

I agree. Though, when(!) we have a proof of the same property for the general entropy, the proof would simply consist of proving that the function gives the entropy Bern(p), or in the q-ary case of, e.g., $qSC_p(1)$, the output distribution of a q-ary symmetric channel, and the remaining part is `exact`ly the respective property of the general entropy. The probability setup would not be exposed (except for the proof that this is the entropy of some probability measure).

For continuity/concavity, I am not sure it is easy enough to be worth it: One would also have to show these properties for the map from p to the PMF. This holds since the pmfs depend affinely on q $P = (1, 0, 0, ...) + (-1, 1/q, 1/q, ...) * p)$. I have no idea if this argument is easy in Lean. I might try it as an exercise (I'm a complete newbie but would be happy if i can contribute to and use Lean for information Theory).

Regarding the point about defining this via the general Shannon entropy, I disagree for practical reasons: it would make the imports of this file *much* heavier, and since the work has already been done it's hardly worth it. Also, note that this function is used in areas like combinatorics where it might be the only bit of information theory that is used, so making its imports heavier would impact the imports of anything downstream as well.

> @dupuisf: Just for clarification: You mean the proofs, not the definition, don't you? I think noone proposed to define `qaryEntropy` in terms of `measureEntropy`.
> 
> I'm not opposed to keeping things separate in principle. Is loading of files a perormance issue in lean, e.g. are they eagerly or lazily loaded?
> 
> That said, if you want to keep this file independent and want to have a proof that the q-ary entropy function gives indeed the entropy of some probability distribution, then this proof must be outsourced, e.g. to accompany the general entropy.

I mean both the proofs and the definition; I think it should be usable without importing a massive chunk of measure theory. Having unnecessary imports has already caused problems in the past (it restricts what can be compiled in parallel, any changes that are made in earlier files triggers a recompilation of all its dependencies, etc). And hopefully, at some point it will become possible for a downstream project to only import the parts of mathlib it actually depends on, which will only add to the benefits of having shallow imports.

And yes, this means that the connection between this and the general Shannon entropy should then be located in some other file.

- Given the discussion so far, I propose to continue with this PR for now without connecting it to the general entropy definition and add the connection in a separate file later, after both this PR and #10493 are merged.
- I'm not completely sure what exactly should the definition be if we include the generalization to "q-ary entropy". If we generalize, I would still prefer to *also* keep the special case of binary entropy as a `def` with a good informative name, because binary entropy seems to be a better known concept than the generalization. 

    The book @dupuisf referenced says that "there is no similar analogue" for the q-ary entropy as the Shannon entropy of a random variable, and uses logs-base-q, so I was bit confused about that, as I wasn't familiar with q-ary entropy until now. Do we want to define `qaryEntropy (q : Nat) (p : Real)` as "the Shannon entropy (measured in Nats) of the random variable '1 with probability (1 - p) and any of 2...q with equal probability' ", so `p * log (q âˆ’ 1) âˆ’ p * log p âˆ’ (1 âˆ’ p) * log (1 âˆ’ p)`? That definition would not even match the definition from the book for q=2 (because of the log-base, which does seem to be there on purpose?!) but if you say this makes sense, let's do it.

> * Given the discussion so far, I propose to continue with this PR for now without connecting it to the general entropy definition and add the connection in a separate file later, after both this PR and [feat: entropy of a measure #10493](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/10493) are merged.
> 
>     * I'm not completely sure what exactly should the definition be if we include the generalization to "q-ary entropy". If we generalize, I would still prefer to _also_ keep the special case of binary entropy as a `def` with a good informative name, because binary entropy seems to be a better known concept than the generalization.
>       The book @dupuisf referenced says that "there is no similar analogue" for the q-ary entropy as the Shannon entropy of a random variable, and uses logs-base-q, so I was bit confused about that, as I wasn't familiar with q-ary entropy until now. Do we want to define `qaryEntropy (q : Nat) (p : Real)` as "the Shannon entropy (measured in Nats) of the random variable '1 with probability (1 - p) and any of 2...q with equal probability' ", so `p * log (q âˆ’ 1) âˆ’ p * log p âˆ’ (1 âˆ’ p) * log (1 âˆ’ p)`? That definition would not even match the definition from the book for q=2 (because of the log-base, which does seem to be there on purpose?!) but if you say this makes sense, let's do it.

Yes, that's basically it. The base of the log is just a scaling factor, and I think in mathlib we'll anyway want to standardize to using natural logs. I guess we can always have `abbrev binaryEntropy := qaryEntropy 2` with specialized lemmas under that name.

> we can always have `abbrev binaryEntropy := qaryEntropy 2` with specialized lemmas under that name

Actually you could make `hâ‚‚` (scoped) notation for `qaryEntropy 2`.

I think, in any case, the base should be emphasized in the documentation: I am not sure where else the function is used, but base $q$ looks like the convention in coding theory to me, since base $q$ is used in the books by Guruswamiâ€“Rudraâ€“Sudan, by [Roth](https://doi.org/10.1017/CBO9780511808968) and in some papers I glanced into. Next week, I could ask a coding theorist if they would be very surprised about base $e$.

Base $q$ makes sense in coding theory since they define the rate of a $k$-dimensional linear code (subspace) in $\mathbb{F}_q^n$ as $k/n$, i.e. they measure in $q$-its.
@jorsn Any news from the coding theorist on how surprising base-e would be?

I doubt it would be that much more surprising than an information theorist seeing natural logs rather than base 2 (i.e. clearly a minority choice, but not shocking). However, it's worth keeping in mind that using a different base than e has a cost in mathlib that doesn't exist on paper: `log` has a more complete API than `logb`, and this is likely to remain that way for the foreseeable future.
My collegue says, it is mostly but not always in base q, and he always checks it. So the natural basis is fine, I think.

Any comments on the definitions or lemma statements?

I'm not sure what to do about linter complaining that `binaryEntropy_one : binaryEntropy 1 = 0` is not in simp-normal-form. Linter says it would want to replace it by `(2-1).log = 0`. What should I do?
- Remove the lemma completely because it "follows obviously" from `qaryEntropy_one` (Personally, I'd rather keep it)
- remove the `simp` attribute
- Add `(2-1).log = 0` as a new simp-lemma (presumably in a different file) as suggested by the linter (??)

The fourth option would be to not make `binaryEntropy` an `abbrev`. (note saying this is good or bad, I haven't thought about it)

Also note that the simp lemma you would need is not `log (2-1) = 0` but rather `2 - 1 = 1` since `log 1 = 0` is already a simp lemma. Or maybe there should be a simproc for numerals instead. (again, not saying this is good or bad, haven't thought about it).

> The fourth option would be to not make `binaryEntropy` an `abbrev`. (note saying this is good or bad, I haven't thought about it)
> 
> Also note that the simp lemma you would need is not `log (2-1) = 0` but rather `2 - 1 = 1` since `log 1 = 0` is already a simp lemma. Or maybe there should be a simproc for numerals instead. (again, not saying this is good or bad, haven't thought about it).

I changed `abbrev` to `def` for `binaryEntropy`. Since many people using `binaryEntropy` will probably not care about `qaryEntropy`, it's maybe better if it doesn't get unfolded into `qaryEntropy`.

All remaining `-- TODO` comments concern lemmas that have assumptions which are not strictly necessary. However, I'm having a hard time proving the statements without those assumptions (it involves proving things like `Â¬DifferentiableAt` in order to use junk values of `deriv`).

Probably nobody will ever need those junk values, however, it would of course be nice overall to never have unnecessary assumptions. I asked for hints about how to do it on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113489-new-members/topic/Proving.20.60.C2.AC.20DifferentiableAt.60/near/412820748) but haven't done it yet. On the other hand, e.g., `deriv2_mul_log` also has unnecessary assumptions, so maybe I shouldn't worry about it?

> All remaining `-- TODO` comments concern lemmas that have assumptions which are not strictly necessary. However, I'm having a hard time proving the statements without those assumptions (it involves proving things like `Â¬DifferentiableAt` in order to use junk values of `deriv`).
>

I asked for hints about how to do it on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113489-new-members/topic/Proving.20.60.C2.AC.20DifferentiableAt.60/near/412820748) but haven't done it yet. On the other hand, e.g., `deriv2_mul_log` also has unnecessary assumptions, so maybe I shouldn't worry about it?

I think there are missing lemmas in mathlib about e.g. `deriv log 0`, etc, for precisely this reason. With those, you could then proceed by cases without too many problems I think. I agree the junk values are not so useful, but removing assumptions from lemma statements makes them easier to use, so it's worth doing.

@dupuisf We can prove `deriv log 0 = 0` using `differentiableAt_log_iff`. However, the approach in the proof of `differentiableAt_log_iff` seems hard to generalize.

Something like `deriv_add` *has to* require that both functions are `differentiableAt` and the converse is false (because "two non-differentiables can cancel each other"). In order to be able to use junk values here, I would have to prove (assuming it's true) something like
```lean4
Â¬ DifferentiableAt ð•œ f x â†’ DifferentiableAt ð•œ g x â†’ Â¬ DifferentiableAt ð•œ (fun y => f y + g y) x
```

and right now I don't really know how to approach it.

In general, the API for proving that things are *not* differentiable does not seem complete or easy to use for a beginner like me.
That's definitely not true as, as you say, non-differentianle functions can add up to a differentiable one

> That's definitely not true as, as you say, non-differentianle functions can add up to a differentiable one

I'm adding a non-differentiable function to a differentiable one and claiming the result is non-differentiable. Do you have a counter-example?

> > That's definitely not true as, as you say, non-differentianle functions can add up to a differentiable one
> 
> I'm adding a non-differentiable function to a differentiable one and claiming the result is non-differentiable. Do you have a counter-example?

You can show non-differentiability by contradiction here: if `g = fâ‚ + fâ‚‚` is differentiable at `x` and so is `fâ‚‚`, then `fâ‚` must also be differentiable there since it's the difference of two differentiable functions.
Sorry, was (mis)reading on my phone

> You can show non-differentiability by contradiction here: if `g = fâ‚ + fâ‚‚` is differentiable at `x` and so is `fâ‚‚`, then `fâ‚` must also be differentiable there since it's the difference of two differentiable functions.

Thanks for the hint! I proved `Â¬ DifferentiableAt ð•œ f x â†’ DifferentiableAt ð•œ g x â†’ Â¬ DifferentiableAt ð•œ (fun y => f y + g y) x`.

However, the same approach doesn't work for `Â¬ DifferentiableAt â„ (fun x => x * log x) 0` because "multiplication with zero" has no functional inverse (let alone one that's differentiable there). In my analysis class many years ago I might have tried an argument (applied to `x * log |x|`, which is what we have here) like 

> it's differentiable in any (punctured) neighborhood of 0 and the derivative grows without bound when approaching 0, hence the derivative at zero cannot exist. 

But I don't know how to do this in Lean (this direction led me to my question at [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113489-new-members/topic/Proving.20.60.C2.AC.20DifferentiableAt.60/near/412820748)).

The proof can can be simplified to this:
```
 lemma deriv_hâ‚‚' {x : â„} (h: x â‰  0) (hh : x â‰  1) :
    deriv (fun p => -p * logâ‚‚ p - (1 - p) * logâ‚‚ (1 - p)) x = logâ‚‚ (1 - x) - logâ‚‚ x := by
  simp [logâ‚‚, logb]
  have : Real.log 2 â‰  0 := by sorry
  have : 1 - x â‰  0 := by sorry
  rw [deriv_sub (by fun_prop (disch:=assumption)) (by fun_prop (disch:=assumption)), deriv.neg]
  simp_rw [mul_div]
  rw [deriv_div_const, deriv_mul_log h, deriv_div_const]
  simp_rw [mul_sub_right_distrib]
  simp only [one_mul]
  rw [deriv_sub (by fun_prop (disch:=assumption)) (by fun_prop (disch:=assumption)),
      deriv_log_one_sub hh]
  rw [deriv_mul (by fun_prop) (by fun_prop (disch:=assumption)), deriv_id'']
  rw [deriv.log (by fun_prop (disch:=assumption))]
  simp only [one_mul, deriv_one_minus]
  field_simp
  ring_nf
  assumption

```

nodes.body: Shouldn't binary entropy be put under InformationTheory? Why not use capital H_2 for the function's name?

@kspalaiologos Thanks for the comment! I moved it to `InformationTheory`. For the name, did you mean to use  `Hâ‚‚` or `H_2`? The danger is that it might be confused with RÃ©nyi entropy (collision entropy), which is written `Hâ‚‚`.

@b-mehta and I have material about the binary entropy function. We needed it a year ago in the context of the progress on the Frankl set family conjecture. I suggest we wait for Bhavik to provide the code to compare.
Yes, I developed that further since this function is fundamental to my Ramsey proof. I will make a detailed comparison in the next day or two.

@YaelDillies @lecopivo @semorrison  
It seems that @b-mehta is not available at the moment. Would you propose to wait or maybe continue with this?
Hopefully I can find the relevant files in the `ramsey` branch of mathlib3.

I guess it's this file?

No, q-ary entropy is very much a generalization of the binary entropy: it's the Shannon entropy of a random variable over {1,...,q}, where 1 has probability 1-x and the rest of the probability is evenly distributed over the rest. It's used for things like bounding the volume of Hamming balls and that sort of thing, much like the binary entropy. And if we're going to standardize to natural logs for defining various versions of the entropy, it should also follow suit.

> * However, if we treat `binaryEntropy` as a "special function that maps Real -> Real", a user of the API shouldn't need to define a random variable (or even know what that is) to use the function and its properties as far as they only concern the function itself (e.g. concavity, differentiability...).

I agree. Though, when(!) we have a proof of the same property for the general entropy, the proof would simply consist of proving that the function gives the entropy Bern(p), or in the q-ary case of, e.g., $qSC_p(1)$, the output distribution of a q-ary symmetric channel, and the remaining part is `exact`ly the respective property of the general entropy. The probability setup would not be exposed (except for the proof that this is the entropy of some probability measure).

For continuity/concavity, I am not sure it is easy enough to be worth it: One would also have to show these properties for the map from p to the PMF. This holds since the pmfs depend affinely on q $P = (1, 0, 0, ...) + (-1, 1/q, 1/q, ...) * p)$. I have no idea if this argument is easy in Lean. I might try it as an exercise (I'm a complete newbie but would be happy if i can contribute to and use Lean for information Theory).

Regarding the point about defining this via the general Shannon entropy, I disagree for practical reasons: it would make the imports of this file *much* heavier, and since the work has already been done it's hardly worth it. Also, note that this function is used in areas like combinatorics where it might be the only bit of information theory that is used, so making its imports heavier would impact the imports of anything downstream as well.
